thread.title: Palisades football team has its sights set on postseason
thread.title_full: Palisades football team has its sights set on postseason

title: Palisades football team has its sights set on postseason
text:
Complete Box Score » 
With three victories in its last four games, Palisades High School’s football team can suddenly see the light at the end of the tunnel. 
The Pirates continued their winning ways on Saturday afternoon with a convincing 35-7 Colonial League victory over Wilson at Smith Field. 
After opening the season with losses to Southern Lehigh (42-21) and Salisbury (41-2), Palisades has evened its record at 3-3 with winless Bangor on the slate next Friday night at Bangor Memorial Park. 
“This was a huge win this week,” said Palisades senior quarterback Austin Krauss , who ran for two scores and passed for another. “I know Bangor isn’t having the greatest year, but you can’t overlook anybody. We want to get to 4-3. We just have to keep working hard.” 
After Bangor, the Pirates finish the regular season with games against winless Pen Argyl sandwiched in between contests against unbeaten Notre Dame and Saucon Valley . 
RELATED : Palisades QB Austin Krauss damages Wilson with his arms and legs 
“We’re fighting for postseason,” said sophomore running back Pat Lodwig , who had a 72-yard touchdown reception and ran 3 yards for another score. “We’re all making each other better. The JVs are making the varsity better. There’s competition all around. Everybody is doing a great job.” 
Sophomore Matt McGrath rushed for 77 yards and a TD and also had an interception. 
Freshman backup quarterback Ethan Brader entered in the fourth quarter with the game in hand and contributed 53 yards rushing on 10 carries. 
Palisades coach Kevin Ronalds was pleased with his offensive line play of tackles Will Sadow and Ben Scoggin, guards Andrew Nickles and Max Allanson-Dundon, center Matt Barnhart and tight end Tyler Marsh, who laid out a vicious block to help free Lodwig on his touchdown reception. 
“We challenged them a little bit, and I thought they controlled the line of scrimmage really well,” Ronalds said. “They came through. There’s not a lot to be disappointed about.” 
The guys up front helped spearhead a Palisades rushing attack that totaled 266 yards. The Pirates had 419 yards from scrimmage overall. 
“We came in and did what we needed to do, and I’m very happy about that,” Ronalds said. “It was a very workmanlike effort.” 
“We’re really coming together now,” Lodwig said. “Things are starting to click. We just need to keep playing like this the next couple weeks.”
